## Step I.I Which questions do I want to answer?

Empirical studies on data donation focus on ...

-   exposure/pathways to news or political content [@loecherbach_what_2024; @xuanjun_gong_media_2023; @wojcieszak_political_2023]
-   social interaction/relationship development [@virtanen_managing_2021; @brinberg_new_2021; @corten_assessing_2025]

## Step I.I Which questions do I want to answer?

Research designs include ...

::: incremental
-   use of **observational data to describe/explain** (e.g., how platforms shape exposure diversity, often via sequential modeling) [@loecherbach_what_2024]
-   **combination with experimental designs** (e.g., interventions, sock puppet training) [@yu_nudging_2024]
-   **triangulation with qualitative methods** (e.g., walk-through-interviews) [@pierce-grove_integrating_2024]
:::

## Step I.I Which questions do I want to answer?

Research designs include ...

-   use of **observational data to describe/explain** (e.g., how platforms shape exposure diversity, often via sequential modeling) [@loecherbach_what_2024]
-   **combination with experimental designs** (e.g., interventions, sock puppet training) [@yu_nudging_2024]
-   **triangulation with qualitative methods** (e.g., walk-through-interviews) [@pierce-grove_integrating_2024]

## Step I.II: Which data donation tool do I use? üñ•Ô∏è

-   Participants "upload" data (nothing is send anywhere)
-   Local extraction, anonymization, & aggregation
-   Users can delete data
-   Informed consent, only then: send to researcher server

## Step I.II: Which data donation tool do I use? üñ•Ô∏è

Choose a tool, e.g., ...

-   **Next** [@boeschoten_etal2023] (different measurements, different platforms)
-   **Data** Donation Module [@pfiffner_data_2022] (different measurements, different platforms)
-   **Dona** [@hakobyan_development_2025] (messaging data, different platforms)
-   **WhatsR** [@kohne_etal2024] (messaging data, WhatsApp)

## Step I.II: How do I anonymize data? üôà

Good anonymization may require...

::: incremental
-   Whitelists/dictionaries of social media accounts
    -   Database of public speakers, Hans-Bredow-Institute ([Link](https://github.com/Leibniz-HBI/DBoeS-data))
    -   Database of news media and their social media handles, University of Vienna ([Link](http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/02673231221112006))
-   Local, in-tool classification (e.g., topic modeling)
-   Manual annotation (e.g., type of contact)
-   Aggregation
:::

## Step I.III: How do I integrate the tool in surveys & recruit participants?

::: incremental
-   Use a single platform for survey & data donation
-   Think about characteristics of your population, e.g., 
    -   Who is using the platform where data should be donated from?
    -   Who is willing and able to share their data?
    -   Can you incentive participants in a meaningful way?
-   ‚ö†Ô∏è Often, the main goal will not (or cannot) be to reach a "representative" sample.

:::
    

## Step I.III: How do I integrate the tool in surveys & recruit participants?

::: incremental
-   Low response rates [e.g., @hase_haim2024a; @keusch_etal2024]

    -   Behavioral intentions as "willingness to donate" high (79-52% of survey respondents)
    -   Actual behavior as "participation in data donation" low (38-1% of survey respondents)
    -   Well known intention-behavior gap [@kmetty_etal2025]

:::

![](images/donation_rate.jpg){
  fig-alt="Nonparticipation rates in data donation"
  fig-align="center"
  style="margin-bottom: 1rem;"

## Step II.II: How do I check for bias?

-   Errors in representation and measurements
    -   based on systematic drop-out [@pak_correcting_2022]
    -   based on systematic misclassification of digital traces [@teblunthuis_etal2024]

üëâ You know the drill: We will talk about this in session 4Ô∏è‚É£.

## Step III: Modelling

![Figure. Data donation study - researcher perspective](images/ablauf-4g.jpg){fig-alt="process of data donation study" fig-align="left" width="300"}

## Step III.I: How do I analyze results?

For inferential modeling, consider [@clemm_von_hohenberg_analysis_2024]....

::: incremental
-   Creating indices from different metrics (e.g., liking, sharing, or commenting) and testing their consistency
-   Accounting for missing data (units, measures)
-   Skewed data (e.g., zero-inflation) and non-linear relationships
-   Hierarchical structure (nested in participants, metrics, platforms) and within/between variance
-   Advanced longitudinal approaches (e.g., with respect to sequences, feedback loops and causal inference)
:::
